Scheme 2 Supramolecular self-assembly coupled with alkali metal molten salts to construct Nv-carbon nitride for efficient photocatalytic H2O2 production Shaoteng Yuan Conceptualization Investigation Methodology Writing – original draft Visualization Manli Yang Validation Investigation Xuefang Lan Writing – review & editing Jinsheng Shi Supervision Project administration ⁎ Qingdao Agricultural University, Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy, China Qingdao Agricultural University, Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy China Qingdao Agricultural University, Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy, China ⁎ Correspondence to: Qingdao Agricultural University, Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy, Chengyang District, Qingdao, China. Qingdao Agricultural University, Department of Chemistry and Pharmacy Chengyang District Qingdao China H2O2 production over carbon nitride photocatalyst is an emerging alternative and ecological solar-driven application. However, bulk carbon nitride (BCN) has stubbornly weak visible light absorption and easy recombination of carriers. Here, a sodium/potassium co-doped N vacancy (Nv) rich carbon nitride was synthesized by a one-step melamine and cyanuric acid self-assembly coupled with alkali metal molten salts. The hybridization of sodium is found to locate on edge site of CN layers, which introduces Nv structure and cyano structure on CN layers, hence modulates the migration of in-plane electrons. The potassium is found to intercalate between CN layers, which promotes carrier transportation between the interlayers. Both effects induce higher carrier transfer efficiency of catalysts and the co-doping of Na and K bring us the optimal sample (CNNK) with an ultra-high production rate (6289.6 μmol/g/h) and apparent quantum yield (44.70 %, 380 nm), which is 124.5 and 10.4 times higher than BCN during the hydrogen peroxide process, respectively. Mechanistic analysis confirms the two-step single-electron oxygen reduction reaction pathway of H2O2 production. This strategy provides an achievable coupling strategy idea to design photocatalysts with elaborate structures for energy conservation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Carbon nitride Photocatalysis Hydrogen peroxide Coupling strategy Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Whether industrial production or daily life, hydrogen peroxide is an efficient green redox reagent that promotes the progress and development of human civilization and is widely used in the textile industry, environmental governance, food and medicine, organic synthesis, and fuel cells, etc [1–3]. In the traditional process, the indirect production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) adopts the industrial production method of anthraquinone, hydrogenation of anthraquinone and then oxygen reduction reaction in an oxygen reduction reaction organic solvent [4]. However, energy-intensive processes and organic compounds such as anthraquinones significantly increase energy consumption and environmental pollution. To overcome the deficiencies mentioned above, another alternative technique has been developed. By selecting suitable noble metal/alloy catalysts, H2O2 can be directly catalyzed from H2 and O2 [5]. Whatever, the direct participation of H2 (g) and O2 (g) bring more uncontrollable factors to the whole process, such as storage, transportation, and reaction. The increase in explosion risk makes it difficult for this process to be popularized a large scale [6]. Simultaneously, the selectivity and production rate of H2O2 production are also severely limited [7]. Therefore, a green-friendly, energy-saving, high-capacity approach is urgently desired and pursued. Photocatalysis has attracted the attention of many researchers due to its environmental friendliness, abundant energy, and sustainable characteristics. To realize the conversion of solar energy to chemical energy, photocatalysis has been widely used in H2 production [8], CO2 reduction [9], N2 fixation [10], etc. However, photocatalytic technology can synthesis hydrogen peroxide as a chemical product and an energy transfer medium [11]. With the assistance of this technical feature, driving hydrogen peroxide production is constantly being tried by researchers [12]. Hiroaki Tada took the lead in the in-situ liquid-phase synthesis of hydrogen peroxide by gold nanoparticles supported titanium dioxide photocatalyst, which confirmed the possibility to synthesize H2O2 using photocatalysis [13]. Afterwards, researchers continued to employ inorganic photocatalytic materials (ZnO [11], WO3 [14], Co3O4 [15], etc.) for H2O2 production. Subsequently, organic polymeric carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has become a popular research object for photocatalysts due to its suitable energy band arrangement, outstanding light absorption performance, and green pollution-free characteristics [16]. Due to the drawbacks of low specific surface area, high recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, and low photoelectric response, bulk intrinsic carbon nitride is difficult to promote the photocatalytic production of H2O2. Shiraishi et al. successfully synthesized H2O2 using an optimized carbon nitride light drive for the first time. Afterwards, the preparation of hydrogen peroxide by modifying carbon nitride materials is receiving greater attention and research. For example, the construction of heterojunction [17,18], non-metal modification [19], metal doping strategies are used to improve the catalytic performance [20]. In any case, relevant literature has shown that the modification of bulk carbon nitride by alkali metals (such as Na +, K +, etc.) is of great help to improve the yield of H2O2 [21]. Zheng et al. reported that potassium hydroxide modified carbon nitride to promote hydrogen peroxide production [22]. Furthermore, Zhao et al. reported that sodium functionalized bulk carbon nitride for producing hydrogen peroxide [23]. However, the single alkali metal-modified carbon nitride has limitations in terms of performance enhancement. The bibasic molten metal salt strategy to achieve co-doped defective states of carbon nitride for catalytic H2O2 production deserves further exploration. Here, supramolecular self-assembly was carried out in a mixed isopropanol solution using melamine and cyanuric acid as precursors ( Scheme 1). Simultaneously, using sodium chloride and potassium chloride molten salts as dopants for mass transfer, a co-doped poly-cyano group carbon nitride is attained. The photocatalytic performance of the tailored CNNK sample to produce H2O2 was 6289.625 μmol/h/g, 124.5 times that of the bulk carbon nitride. In addition, the catalytic apparent quantum yield (AQY) is 44.7 % at the monochromatic wavelength of 380 nm. On the one hand, the introduction of sodium ions builds N defect states in the carbon nitride plane, and the introduction of sp-hybridized cyano groups provides a more vital driving force for the separation of photogenerated carriers. On the other hand, introducing potassium ions improves the interlayer conductivity of carbon nitride, which unclogs the in-plane localized electrons. Furthermore, this paper also analyzes the advantages of non-single alkali metal doping or defect structures guided by post-processing strategies. This work provides deeper insights into the rational design of photocatalysts, from the selection of design strategies to the co-production of H2O2 by alkali metal doping-assisted construction of defect states and guides the catalytic applications of other photocatalytic semiconductors. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Melamine (C3H6N6), cyanuric acid (C3H3N3O), sodium chloride (NaCl), and potassium chloride (KCl) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Isopropyl alcohol (C3H8O) were brought from Macklin. MilliQ ultra-pure water with a resistivity higher than 18.2 MΩ·cm was used in whole experiments. All reagents are analytically pure, and there was no further purification before use. 2.2 Synthesis of materials 2.2.1 One-pot alkali metal molten salt coupled self-assembly to build nitrogen-vacant carbon nitride First, a mixed solution consisting of 180 ml of water and 20 ml of isopropanol was prepared. Then, 5 g melamine, 5 g cyanuric acid, and 10 g chloride (NaCl: KCl= 1:1) were added to the above solution, respectively. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h. The mixed solution was filtered and dried in a vacuum drying oven overnight. The mixed precursor (2 g) was ground and calcined at 550 ℃ for 4 h (5 ℃/min, Ar). The product was washed eight times with water and then vacuum-dried at 60 ℃ for 12 h. The sample was collected, grounded, and marked as CNNK. Furthermore, the CNN and CNK samples were modified with NaCl and KCl, respectively. As a comparison, polymeric carbon nitride with only melamine and cyanuric acid precursor and without any NaCl or KCl addition was also prepared, the final product was denoted as the polymeric carbon nitride (CN). 2.2.2 Synthesis of bulk carbon nitride (BCN) and alkali metal post-modified carbon nitride Typically, 2 g of melamine and 2 g cyanuric acid is finely ground in a mortar. Then, the mixture was transferred to a cylindrical crucible and directly calcined for 4 h at 550 ℃ with a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1 in a muffle furnace. The product was washed, dried, and ground denoted the bulk carbon nitride (BCN). The carbon nitrides prepared via post-modification strategy was carried out by grounding BCN and chloride (NaCl, KCl and NaCl/KCl) first. Then, the mixed precursor was calcined at 550 °C for 2 h, and the corresponding products were named CN-N, CN-K, and CN-N-K. In addition, m-CNNK was also prepared by mechanical grinding 2 g of melamine, 2 g cyanuric acid and certain amount of NaCl/KCl directly, followed by calcination at 550 °C for 4 h (5 ℃/min, Ar) and corresponding sample drying. 2.3 Characterization Micromorphology and structures can be characterized by HR-TEM (JEM-2100PLUS) and SEM (Zeiss Gemini 300). Crystallographic information was collected by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8 Advance diffractometer, Bruker) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer using the KBr pellet as the background. The 13C solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were measured on the JNM-ECZ600R. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was implemented on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer using 150 W Al Kα radiation as the exciting source, and all the binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were examined by a UV–vis spectrophotometer (UV-3900Plus) using BaSO4 as a reflectance standard and the absorption was converted to F(R) by the Kubelka–Munk method. The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were detected by the Hitachi High-Technologies (F-7000) luminescence spectrometer with an excitation wavelength of 380 nm. The photoelectrical properties were carried out on an electrochemical workstation (CHI 760E). Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopy was used to detect the signals of free radicals (•O2 −) on a Bruker A300 spectrometer. Oxygen temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was measured on Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. 2.4 Photoelectrochemical experiments The Rotating Ring Disk Electrode (RRDE) was measured on a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation using a three-electrode battery. Preparation of working electrode: Firstly, 5 mg catalyst, 950 μL ethanol: H2O (4:1), and 50 μL Nafion and ultrasonicate for 3 h to disperse uniformly. Then, 12.6 μL of sample dispersion droplets were measured twice and applied to a clean glassy carbon electrode (0.255 mg/cm2), and the samples were naturally dried for testing. Secondly, under the conditions of pure oxygen and room air, the LSV was tested at a scanning speed of 5 mV/ and a rotation speed of 1600 rpm under 0.1 M PBS (pH = 7), and the data were recorded and saved (the ring voltage was set to 1.4 V). The reference electrode was an Ag/AgCl electrode, and the counter electrode was a Pt sheet electrode. The photocurrent measurements, Mott-Schottky (M-S) analyses, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) were performed on the CHI760E electrochemical workstation (CH Instruments, Inc., Shanghai) by using a standard three-electrode system. The Pt electrode as counter electrode, saturated calomel electrode as reference electrode, as-prepared sample coated ITO glass as the working electrode and 0.5 mol L−1 Na2SO4 solution as electrolyte were applied in the measurements, respectively. The working electrode was prepared as follows. Typically, 10 mg catalyst, 20 μL acetic acid, ethanol, coated on 1 × 1 cm ITO glass, dried in vacuum at 80 °C overnight. Xe lamp (300 W, PLS-SXE300) with a 420 nm cut-off filter was used as the light source for photocurrent response tests. All the above electrochemical measurements were taken at room temperature. Mott-Schottky plots were obtained by three sweeps in a voltage range of 0 ∼ 1 V with an amplitude of 10 mV at the selected frequencies of 1.0 kHz. 2.5 Photocatalytic activity evaluation The photocatalytic activity was evaluated by catalytic performance for H2O2 production. In the 250 ml reactor, 50 mg of catalyst was mixed and dispersed with 50 ml of aqueous ethanol (10 %). A 300 W Xenon lamp (PLS-SXE 300, Beijing Perfectlight) with a 420 nm cut-off filter was used as the light source. Before the reaction, the system was purged with high-purity O2 for 30 min to make the system reach the equilibrium of adsorption and desorption. 1 ml of the solution was drawn from the system every 15 min and filtered through a 0.2 µm membrane. The whole process of the reaction is controlled by circulating cooling water. After proper dilution, the concentration of H2O2 was analyzed by the standard iodometric method. Furthermore, the apparent quantum yield (AQY) for H2O2 production was calculated by the equation: AQY = Number of produced H 2 O 2 molecules × 2 Number of incident photons × 100 % The H2O2 decomposition reaction was carried out under the same experimental equipment. For a typical experiment, 50 ml of H2O2 solution (500 μM) was taken into a reactor and cooled down keeping the temperature constant by circulating cooling water. 50 mg of catalyst was added to the reactor and was exposed to light illumination with constant stirring. After the reaction, the catalyst was centrifuged and H2O2 was analyzed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition and structure of as-prepared samples With the benefit of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), the microscopic morphologies and structural characteristics of bulk carbon nitride (BCN) were demonstrated in Fig S1a. Bulk carbon nitride exhibits its typical block-plate morphology, mainly manifested in the relatively flat and thick plane layers. Besides, melamine and cyanuric acid-polymerized carbon nitride (CN) exhibits ultrathin curly lamellar structure, originating from the polymerization crosslinking process and -NH2 released during calcination (Fig. S1b). Furthermore, the introduction of sodium or potassium ions leads to more fragmentation of CN slices with vacancies and makes the surface rough and rugged, respectively (Fig S1c, d). However, CNNK locally presents a microtubular structure owing to the polymerization of the precursor in isopropanol solution, and the co-doping of sodium and potassium ions makes carbon nitride exhibit an irregular morphology of ion thermal etching ( Fig. 1a) [24,25]. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images and processing details of the CNNK sample are shown in Fig. 1b. The HRTEM images demonstrate the wanton growth of CNNK which is consistent with SEM patterns and exhibit an enlarged (100) interplanar spacing with a width of 1.72 nm (Inset). A modest enlargement of the interplanar spacing may originate from the embedment of metal ions that matches the aforementioned reports [26,27]. As shown in Fig. 1c, the element distribution spectra (EDS) are used to demonstrate the successful introduction of sodium/potassium ions and the distribution of elements. Remarkably, the distribution of Na is almost identical to that of C, N and O elements, whereas the distribution of K is more dispersed and homogeneous. This suggests that Na is uniformly distributed within the bulk phase of CN, while K is distributed in a completely different position to Na. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns are recorded to probe the phase structure of as-prepared various g-C3N4 materials, as shown in Fig. 2a. Typically, XRD patterns of BCN samples showed two characterization peaks at about 27.2° and 13.0°, originating from the interlayer stacking (002) and the inner planar structure packing (100) of tri-s-triazine units, respectively [28]. Compared to BCN, the CN samples obtained from our strategy and post-treatment strategy all shows weaker diffraction peaks, which suggests that both strategies significantly suppress the crystallinity of carbon nitride. Nevertheless, the introduction of alkali metal from our strategy and the post-treatment strategy shows different effects on the crystal phase of carbon nitride. Firstly, the post-treatment strategy introduces no peak shift of (100) on diffraction results except for Na and K co-doping, indicating that it exerts no significant effect on the crystal phase. This phenomenon suggests that the post-treatment strategy mainly exerts effects on the carbon nitride edge, called the edge clipping effect. Secondly, the pre-introduction of Na shifts the (100) crystal peak of carbon nitride to a smaller diffraction angle (8–9°), suggesting that sodium ions play a major role in the plane [29]. Different from Na modification, the potassium has no objective effect on the diffraction peak position of (100), but shifts the (002) peak towards smaller degree. The (002) diffraction peak symbolizes the interlayer stacking of heptazine rings, hence this indicates that K locates between CN layers as intercalation [30]. The diffraction lines become diffused and widened after K modification. Combined with Sherrer's formula, it is shown that the introduction of K + leads to a smaller grain size of CNNK, which is consistent with the SEM images. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was employed to identify the surface functionality of the photocatalysts. Compared to BCN, all materials have similar absorption peaks and exhibit similar skeletal structures. Typically, the out-of-plane bending mode of the heptazine unit located at 812 cm −1 (purple dotted line) and the bands in the range of 1200–1700 cm −1 (right rectangle frame selection) correspond to the skeletal vibrations of aromatic CN heterocycles (Fig. 2b) [26,31]. A significant absorption peak appeared at 2178 cm −1 (left rectangle frame selection) with the alkali metal-doped carbon nitride structure. Generally speaking, this absorption peak tends to form during the treatment of polymeric carbon nitride with salts or alkali metals which is attributed to the stretching vibration of the -CN (cyano group) [28]. However, the normalized FTIR curves show that the construction of cyano groups annihilates the broad absorption peaks of the hydrophilic groups, which tend to be assigned to amino groups/surface hydroxyl groups located at 3400 − 3000 cm −1. Solid-state 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) was further performed to identify the structural differences between BCN and CNNK [23]. As shown in Fig. 2c, both BCN and CNNK exhibit two strong resonance signals at 156.6 and 164.9 ppm, respectively, and they correspond to N-CN and NC-NH atoms in the heptazine rings [32]. Notably, the co-doping of Na-K brings a weaker signal response that the heptazine ring structure is affected. Compared with BCN, the peaks (NC-NH) of CNNK shifted to the high field attributed to fewer NHx species and the presence of additional groups in -C ≡ N that caused the broke electronic balance and electronic delocalization (Inset: a zoomed-in view of the 1.4 ppm shift) [26,33]. The cyano group destroys the heptazine ring structure, which can directly affect the electronic structure of BCN. Furthermore, the abruptness of the sodium cyanaminate moiety can be observed, which is consistent with previous literature (Red pentagram) [23]. The room-temperature electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra (Fig. 2d) were further accomplished to examine the local nitrogen vacancies (Nv) [25]. The Lorentzian lines of BCN and CNNK samples are centered at the g value of 2.0036, indicating the same type of unpaired electrons on the aromatic C-N heterocycles. The CNNK has a stronger signal response [34]. Therefore, the heptazine ring structure is cleaved, and the fringe structures of -C ≡ N/Na + are formed, consistent with the previous literature report [29]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and its high-resolution fine spectroscopy provide strong evidence for the successful introduction of alkali metals and elemental compound states ( Fig. 3) [35]. Fig. 3c shows the survey XPS spectra of all samples (BCN, CN, CNN, CNK, and CNNK). The BCN and CN curves exhibit significant C 1 s, N 1 s, and O 1 s signals without any other elemental response. However, the emission peaks of CNN and CNK at 1071 eV (Na 1s) and 293 eV (K 2p) confirm the doping of Na and K elements, respectively, while CNNK exhibits the feature of co-doping. In addition, the Cl element was almost completely removed during the catalyst preparation process. High-resolution fine spectrum C 1s were revealed by the apparent changes of the major and minor peaks at 284.8, 286.1, and 288.2 eV, assigned to sp2-hybridized carbon of C-C/CC, CN/C-O, and NC-N, respectively (Fig. 3a) [26]. The maintenance of all distinctive peaks confirms the retention of the tri-s-triazine heterocycle. Nevertheless, the percentage of the deconvoluted peaks of CN/C-O and NC-N both increased with alkali metal modification. On the contrary, the ratio of CN-C continued to decline. Therefore, this feature exemplifies the triazine structure destruction and cyano derivatization well. In other words, the introduction of alkali metals forms Na/K-N bonds accompanied by the formation of N vacancies. It is worth noting that although both Na ions and K ions affect the N-CN ratio, the similar ratios of N-CN in CNK (22.26 %) and CNNK (21.15 %) samples suggest that K ion doping plays a more significant role (Table S1). As shown in Fig. 3b, the N 1 s peak at 398.6 eV is assigned to pyridinic N (CN-C) and cyano group, and the signal around 400 eV is usually attributed to the graphitic N (N-C3), while the binding energy peak at 401 eV is appointed to an amine group (N-HX) [35]. Noticeably, the N-C3 proportion almost entirely disappeared after modification. Simultaneously, the transfer of amino groups to high binding energies suggests the shielding effect of adjacent cyano groups [36]. Thus, a reasonable deduction is that the alkali metal ions occupy the original graphitic N sites, and charges within carbon nitride are locally regulated. In addition, the CN-C ratio gradually decreases, which is also consistent with the deconvoluted peaks of C 1s. Furthermore, more detailed information about sodium and potassium elements is shown in Fig. 3d. The CNN and CNNK samples keep exactly similar deconvolution peaks located at 1071.7 eV except for the difference in intensity caused by different amounts of doping (Fig. 3d, left). Similarly, the K 2p spectrum is exemplified in CNK and CNNK samples (Fig. 3d, right). The binding energy distance between K p3/2 and K p1/2 is 2.79 eV, consistent with the literature reports [26]. According to XPS quantification, potassium ions are twice as much as sodium ions. The binding energy of the same element did not shift after adding the different elements, which confirmed that Na + and K + did not interact with each other. 3.2 Photocatalytic hydrogen peroxide generation Photocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) was employed to evaluate the performance of photocatalysts under visible light irradiation ( > 420 nm ) . As shown in Fig. 4a, photocatalytic production of H2O2 is in order of CNNK, m-CNNK, CNK, CN-N-K, CN-K, CNN, CN-N, CN, and BCN. Above all, BCN exhibited poor catalytic performance since the rapid charge recombination and poor selectivity and the photocatalytic production rate of H2O2 is only 50.5 μmol/g/h. Polymeric carbon nitride (CN) properties up to 200 μmol/g/h owing to high crystallinity promoted by the self-assembly process of melamine and cyanuric acid (Fig. 2a). The CNN sample exhibits a H2O2 yield of 966.3 μmol/g/h with the incorporation of sodium. This is likely due to the formation of the sodium cyanamide structure, which facilitates the separation of the in-plane photogenerated carriers. The potassium-treated carbon nitride (CNK) can boost the H2O2 yield to 3760.6 μmol/g/h. However, the low crystallinity of CNK may limit further enhancement of its catalytic performance. Although the alkali metal post-treatment of CN, known as the edge pruning strategy, improves the production of H2O2, it is impossible to design the internal regulation of the polymerized carbon nitride. Owing to the limited influence on the crystalline and chemical structure of the intrinsic carbon nitride, CN-N-K, CN-K, and CN-N exhibited lower yields of 2152.9 μmol/g/h, 1859.3 μmol/g/h, and 450.7 μmol/g/h, respectively. On the contrary, the self-assembly strategy combined with molten salt of NaCl/KCl can achieve top-down alkali metal co-doping on CN, which can significantly improves H2O2 yield (Table S2) [34]. The activity of CNNK for photocatalytic H2O2 production was dramatically increased, with the highest H2O2 evolution rate reaching 6289.6 μmol/g/h, which is about 124.6 times that of BCN. The ability of photocatalysts to decompose H2O2 is an essential indicator for evaluating hydrogen peroxide production. Hydrogen peroxide degradation experiments show that the alkali metal co-modified carbon nitride is the most active candidate for H2O2 decomposition (Fig. 4b). Although CNNK exhibited good activity for H2O2 decomposition, its activity on H2O2 production is significantly higher than its activity on H2O2 decomposition, which allowed the accumulation of H2O2 during reaction. Afterwards, photocatalytic H2O2 generation under the different atmospheres was tested in the suspension solutions with O2, N2, and air. When air and N2 replaced O2 to participate in the reaction, the photocatalytic H2O2 production rates were 3930.1 and 793.2 μmol/g/h, respectively (Fig. 4c). Obviously, oxygen gas is an essential factor in the production process of H2O2, which is very important for inferring the reaction mechanism [37]. Since H2O2 production involves a gas-liquid-solid three-phase reaction, the pH of the aqueous solution should be considered for its effect on the production rate [38]. As shown in Fig. 4d, CNNK exhibits more excellent H2O2 production capacity under acidic solution (pH = 3) with 8334.3 μmol/g/h. Nevertheless, the H2O2 production ability of CNNK in alkaline solution (pH = 9) is only a meagre 662.2 μmol/g/h and the production rate is severely limited. For CNNK, the participation of more protons promoted the photocatalytic production of H2O2. Although the acidic conditions have an appropriate promotion to produce H2O2 from BCN, this promotion is still relatively modest, which may be caused by the intrinsic properties of the catalyst. Furthermore, the formation (Kf) and the decomposition (Kd) rate constant of H2O2 is a necessary means to assess the kinetic productivity of the catalysts (Fig. 4e) [38,39]. The generation rate and degradation rate are fitted by zero-order reaction fitting and pseudo-first-order reaction fitting, respectively, so the kinetic equation can be obtained by Eq. (1): (1) [ H 2 O 2 ] = k f k d × 1 − exp ⁡ ( − k d × t where t is the reaction time (min) and [H2O2] is the concentration of produced H2O2 (μM L−1). The experimental data were fitted with the above kinetic equation to obtain k f and k d which are listed in Table S3. All prepared samples exhibited an effect on H2O2 decomposition that was attributed to the reaction of H2O2 with the semiconductor excited state electrons (H2O2 + e − → •OH + OH − ) . In any case, CNNK presents the highest k f (106.4 μM min− 1) which is the most critical factor. By comparison, the k d of CNNK is 20 times that of BCN but much lower than the k f of 126.2 times that lays a solid foundation for CNNK to promote H2O2 synthesis. The kinetic advantages of hydrogen peroxide synthesis exhibited by CNNK endow the catalyst with the possibility of large-scale application. Moreover, the photo-corrosion resistance and regeneration ability of the catalyst are important indicators for practical application. As shown in Fig. 4f, the CNNK sample still maintained the hydrogen peroxide production rate as high as 5765.3 μmol/g/h after four production cycles. In addition, XRD diffraction analysis and FTIR spectra further confirmed that CNNK retained the original crystal structure and absorption peaks of functional groups (Fig. S2a, b). The photocatalytic performance of CNNK was quite stable. 3.3 Two-electron ORR pathway The hydrogen peroxide production pathway is related to the reaction rate and selectivity that a selective two-electron transfer process should be promoted [40]. The rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE) test confirmed the 2 e − oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) pathway of CNNK wherein the disc current signals ( I d ) mainly stemmed from the O2 reduction reactions and the Pt-ring current signals ( I r ) originated from the 2 e − oxidation of H2O2 produced from the disc ( Fig. 5) [23,40]. Under the oxygen atmosphere, both the electrodes coated by CN and CNNK samples exhibited similarly I d signals, while the current signals were severely annihilated when the electrodes were saturated with air (Fig. 5d). This firmly confirms that O2 is a crucial part of the ORR reaction. Whatever, the highest I r current signal was observed in the CNNK testing systems within the voltage range of 0–0.5 V (vs. RHE) under the O2 atmosphere (Fig. 5a). Also, the Ir/Id ratio of CNNK is superior to that of BCN in any atmosphere that shows CNNK samples are more likely to drive H2O2 production [41]. Furthermore, the selectivity of H2O2 production reflects the utilization of photogenerated carriers, which can be quantitatively analyzed by the following formula Eq. (2): (2) H 2 O 2 % = 200 × I r / N I d + I r / N where I d is the disc current, I r is the ring current, and N is the collection efficiency (N = 0.37). As shown in Fig. 5b, the CNNK system exhibits excellent selectivity for hydrogen peroxide production under air conditions, almost twice that of the BCN system. Nevertheless, when more O2 participates in the reaction, the selectivity decreases, which may be because the participation of the reactants affects the rate-determining step of the reaction and reduces the utilization of O2 [42]. The average number of electrons (n) involved in the overall O2 reduction was determined by the following formula Eq. (3): (3) n = 4 I d I d + I r / N where I d is the disc current, I r is the ring current, and N is the collection efficiency (N = 0.37). The electron transfer number of CNNK samples is closer to 2.0 than BCN, indicating that the photocatalytic hydrogen peroxide production is a 2 e − ORR pathway (Fig. 5e) [43]. Accordingly, the RRDE measurements thus demonstrate that CNNK exhibits kinetic advantage and selectivity for 2 e − ORR compared to BCN [40]. 3.4 Photochemical test and band structure The improvement of H2O2 performance may be caused by the change of semiconductor energy band structure caused by alkali metal doping. Above all, UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectrum (UV–vis DRS) was used to investigate the optical absorption properties of all samples [44]. As depicted in Fig. 6a, the light absorption edge of BCN was located at ~ 450 nm, while the absorption edge of CNNK shifted to ~500 nm. A prominent Ulbach band tail is observed, which may originate from the abundance of structural defects in the motif template [34]. Moreover, the redshifts of the absorption band edges of all samples are consistent with the hydrogen peroxide production rate and light captivation was enhanced in the range from 500 to 800 nm. The wavelength-dependent apparent quantum yield (AQY) for hydrogen peroxide production was measured, which is often used to distinguish whether a photoinduced carrier drives the present chemical process or not [45]. Fig. 6b presented the AQY of the BCN and CNNK samples (detailed data of measured photoactivity and light intensity are listed in Table S4) at monochromatic waves at 380 nm, 400 nm, and 500 nm, respectively. The AQY decreases with an increasing wavelength of the incident light, which corroborated the optical absorption capacity of the testing samples [46]. However, the CNNK achieves a superior level with a high AQY of 44.7 % under the designated monochromic light 380 nm, which exceeds the BCN 10 times (4.46 %). Subsequently, the direct band gaps (Eg) could be obtained by constructing Tauc plots (Eq. 4) based on the transformed Kubelk-Munk function and photon energy. (4) α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n / 2 where E g , α, h, ν , and A denote the bandgap, optical absorption coefficient, Plank's constant, photonic frequency, and a proportionality constant, respectively [47]. The value of n is four because carbon nitride is an indirect bandgap semiconductor owing to the positive slope of the Mott-Schottky curve (Fig. S3) [44]. As illustrated in Fig. 6d, the E g of the BCN, CN, CNN, CNK, and CNNK were estimated to be 2.41, 2.53, 2.57, 2.53, 2.37 eV, respectively. Fig. 6c shows the valence band spectrum of a series of samples, combined with the following formula (Eq. 5): EVB = Φ + EVB-XPS-4.44 (5). where EVB, Φ and EVB-XPS represents valence band position, the electron work function (4.2 eV) and the value of valence band maximum, respectively. Thus the EVB values were calculated to be 2.09, 1.86, 2.25, 2.44 and 2.03 eV (vs. NHE), respectively, while the corresponding ECB values were − 0.32, - 0.67, - 0.32, - 0.09 and - 0.34 eV through the equation (Eq. 6): (6) E VB = E CB + E g where E CB represents the conduction band. The band structure arrangement is arranged in an orderly manner ( Fig. 7). 3.5 Carrier separation efficiency The mobility and separation efficiency of photogenerated charges in the photocatalysts are also crucial factors governing photocatalytic activity [41]. Sodium-potassium ion-assisted construction of cyano groups improves the utilization efficiency of photogenerated carriers in the heptaazine motifs. Photoluminescence Spectroscopy (PL) was applied to investigate the interfacial charge separation characteristics of the samples. As shown in Fig. 6e, either the alkali metal molten salt strategy co-doping or the post-pruning strategy to introduce sodium/potassium can significantly suppress the recombination of photogenerated carriers, so the PL spectrum suffers from annihilation. Simultaneously, in-situ potassium ion doping suppresses carrier recombination better than sodium ion doping which may be associated with the interlayer doing sites, but this conclusion does not apply under the post-processing strategy [48]. Furthermore, the molten salt strategy sodium/potassium doped carbon nitride undergoes a noticeable stokes shift that probably stemmed from the build of Nv, while "pruning" eventually leads to a relatively blue shift [49]. Time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) spectra were analyzed to gain profound insights into the charge transfer kinetics and lifetimes of photoexcited carriers for BCN and CNNK samples (Fig. 6f) [44]. The two-exponential model was employed to fit the average radiative lifetime ( τ avg ) of the fluorescence decay curve using the following formula (Eq. 5): τ avg = ( A 1 τ 1 2 + A 2 τ 2 2 ) / ( A 1 τ 1 + A 2 τ 2 ) (5). where A 1 , A 2 , τ 1 , and τ 2 denote the normalized amplitudes of each decay component and values of the lifetime components, respectively. The specific values are listed in table S5. The τ avg values of BCN and CNNK were 4.10 and 1.65 ns, respectively. The increase in the ratio A 1 of 49.59–64.43 % proves that more excited electrons transition from the conduction band to the excitation-mediated trap state, which are subsequently conducted to the Nv-mediated trap state [50]. Namely, the introduction of N v (-C ≡ N , sp) within the heptaazine framework (-CN-C, sp2) and the intercalation of K ions facilitated the samples with better carrier mobility. It resulted in the transfer of activated electrons to foreign oxygen to catalyze the generation of superoxide radicals [51]. The enhanced charge transport efficiency is further confirmed by the increased photocurrent and decreased electrochemical impedance. As shown in Fig. 6g, the CNNK samples exhibit a smaller semicircle Nyquist curve than both CNN and CNK. Therefore, the conduction of carriers on CNNK has less resistance, which implies that the samples have higher separation efficiency of widespread carriers and a faster charge transfer rate [52]. Additionally, Fig. 6h shows a rapid photocurrent response for samples on regular switch on−off cycles. The photocurrent intensity of CNNK is as high as 2.0 μA cm −2 in the first cycle, which is significantly better than that of the alkali metal monohybrid CNN, CNK samples. The BCN displays a weak photocurrent density of 0.1 μA cm −2, revealing the rapid recombination of photogenerated charge carriers (Fig. S4). We speculate that the co-doping of sodium and potassium promotes the carrier conduction within and among the layers, respectively. The massive discrepancy between samples reflects that the modified sample can generate more captured photoelectrons to participate in the ORR, consistent with the enhanced photocatalytic activity. Taken together, the above characterization confirms that the fast exciton dissociation with concomitant high carrier mobility can result in photogenerated electrons finding trap sites (and moving to them) and reacting with adsorbed oxygen molecules [53]. The desorption of O2 on the solid surface of the catalytic material is an important factor affecting the production of H2O2. By O2-TPD analysis, the physicochemical properties of oxygen adsorbed on the surface of the materials were examined (Fig. S5). The CNNK sample exhibited O2 desorption peak with higher integral area than the BCN, revealing the higher O2 adsorption capacity of CNNK. Besides, CNNK showed O2 desorption peaks at 231 °C and higher temperature, indicate a much stronger O2 adsorption strength on CNNK. Such stronger interaction between CNNK surface and O2 is crucial for the fixation of O2, the transfer of electrons to O2, and the subsequent generation of superoxide radicals [23]. 3.6 4. H2O2 production mechanism Generally, there are two routes to produce H2O2 by photocatalysis: two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and two-electron water oxidation reaction (WOR). Specifically, ORR and WOR can achieve by the following formula (Eq. 6, 7) [54]: O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2 O 2 E = 0.695 V vs. NHE(6). 2 H 2 O → H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e − E = 1.760 V vs. NHE(7). Combined with the energy band structure (Fig. 6g), whether it is an ORR or a WOR process, the purpose of producing H2O2 can be achieved thermodynamically. However, ethanol as a superior hole ( h + ) scavenger provides a specific environment for H2O2 production by 2 e − ORR. Simultaneously, the electron transfer number (n) tested by RRDE also confirmed that hydrogen peroxide production mainly originated from the ORR pathway rather than the water oxidation process (Fig. 5e). The 2 e − oxygen reduction to H2O2 pathway consists of a two-step single-electron path (O2 → • O 2 − → H2O2) or a one-step two-electron route (O2 → H2O2) [55]. To elucidate the specific reaction mechanism, 5,5-dimethyl-1--pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) spin-trapping ESR technology was used to investigate superoxide radicals under dark and visible light ( > 420 nm), respectively (Fig. 5c) [41,56]. Under dark conditions, BCN and CNNK samples exhibited similar signals. However, CNNK samples exhibited an ultrahigh response signal than BCN under the illumination of the light source, proving that the defect N activates dissolved oxygen more to generate superoxide radicals. Additionally, the photocatalytic performance of H2O2 production was severely restrained when p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) was added to the reaction system. As shown in Fig. 5f, p-BQ successfully reduced the H2O2 production from 6289.6 to 906 μmol/g/h, implying that the formation of H2O2 got through the two-step single-electron pathway by CNNK and • O 2 − was a crucial intermediate. (Insets: the dynamics of yields). Furthermore, dissolved oxygen is an essential raw material in the production process of hydrogen peroxide which can be confirmed by the rate of H2O2 under different atmospheres (Fig. 4c). In addition, pH is another factor that affects the performance of H2O2 by referring to Eq. (6) and performance differences (Fig. 4d). Based on the above results, the possible mechanism for CNNK to photocatalytically reduce O2 to generate H2O2 was proposed ( Scheme 2). Explicitly, the basic process of photocatalytic production of hydrogen peroxide can be divided into the following steps: Firstly, the CNNK sample produces more carriers under visible light owing to the narrowed band gap (Eg) [57]; Secondly, the sodium-potassium co-intercalation to construct Nv synergistically promotes the interfacial charge transfer and separation of photogenerated carriers and improves the separation efficiency. The solid electron-withdrawing ability of N defects caused by N vacancies and cyano groups facilitates more electrons to migrate from the CB to the excitation-mediated trap state while Na + and K + promote in-plane and inter-layer conduction, respectively [22]. Thirdly, the activated electron reacts with the dissolved oxygen molecules and protons in the trap to generate H2O2 through a two-step single-electron pathway that generates superoxide radicals [39]. 4 Conclusion In summary, we employ melamine and cyanuric acid self-assembly coupled with alkali metal molten salts to assist the construction of sodium/potassium co-doped Nv carbon nitride catalysts. The optimal sample CNNK exhibits a catalytic performance of 6289.6 μmol/g/h and an apparent quantum yield of 44.7 % at 380 nm in H2O2 production, which are 124.5 and 10.4 times higher than those of BCN, respectively. Note that sodium can introduce Nv defective and cyano groups on CN layers, which modulates the transfer of in-plane electrons. While, potassium can intercalate between CN layers, promoting interlayer transportation of carriers. The elaborate design of the carbon nitride structure modification was found to significantly improve the carrier separation and conduction efficiency and improve the kinetic characteristics of the carriers by analyzing the hydrogen peroxide yield and optoelectronic properties. The extraordinary binding of O2 provides higher possibility of •O2 - formation, hence higher production of H2O2 on the CNNK surface. Simultaneously, the two-step single-electron ORR pathway for hydrogen peroxide production was identified by RRDE, ESR, and p-BQ trap experiments, and the photocatalytic reaction mechanism was clarified. Therefore, this study provides insights into the molten salt strategy to guide the alkali metal doping-assisted construction of Nv-carbon nitride and provides a guiding idea for the efficient production of H2O2 from the kinetics of catalytically driven carrier separation. coredata.dc:description: H2O2 production over carbon nitride photocatalyst is an emerging alternative and ecological solar-driven application. However, bulk carbon nitride (BCN) has stubbornly weak visible light absorption and easy recombination of carriers. Here, a sodium/potassium co-doped N vacancy (Nv) rich carbon nitride was synthesized by a one-step melamine and cyanuric acid self-assembly coupled with alkali metal molten salts. The hybridization of sodium is found to locate on edge site of CN layers, which introduces Nv structure and cyano structure on CN layers, hence modulates the migration of in-plane electrons. The potassium is found to intercalate between CN layers, which promotes carrier transportation between the interlayers. Both effects induce higher carrier transfer efficiency of catalysts and the co-doping of Na and K bring us the optimal sample (CNNK) with an ultra-high production rate (6289.6 μmol/g/h) and apparent quantum yield (44.70 %, 380 nm), which is 124.5 and 10.4 times higher than BCN during the hydrogen peroxide process, respectively. Mechanistic analysis confirms the two-step single-electron oxygen reduction reaction pathway of H2O2 production. This strategy provides an achievable coupling strategy idea to design photocatalysts with elaborate structures for energy conservation.
coredata.dc:title: Supramolecular self-assembly coupled with alkali metal molten salts to construct Nv-carbon nitride for efficient photocatalytic H2O2 production
